metadata.chief_complaint: eczema follow-up, developed reaction to new steroid cream, need alternative

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi, how's Grace's eczema doing with the new cream?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Actually, that's why we're here. She had a reaction to it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Oh no. Tell me what happened.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: We started the triamcinolone cream you prescribed. After two days, the areas where we put it got really red and bumpy. Worse than the eczema itself.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Did it itch more or less?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Way more. She was scratching like crazy. I stopped the cream and it got better over a few days.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me take a look at her skin now.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I can see some residual irritation on her arms where you applied it. The rest of her eczema patches actually look worse because we haven't been treating them.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I was afraid to put anything on her. Is she allergic to steroid creams?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It sounds like a contact allergy to something in that particular cream. Could be the active ingredient or one of the inactive ingredients like a preservative.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Can she use any steroid creams?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Probably, just not triamcinolone or creams with similar preservatives. I'm going to try her on a different one, mometasone, which has a different formulation.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What if she reacts to that one too?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Start with a small test area, like one patch on her arm. If it looks good after two days, you can use it more broadly. If she reacts, stop and call me.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. That sounds safe.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm going to document triamcinolone as an allergy in her chart. The reaction was contact dermatitis, localized rash and itching.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Should I tell other doctors about this?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, mention it any time she's prescribed a topical steroid so they can choose a different one.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What about her regular moisturizer? Can she keep using that?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Which one is she using?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: CeraVe cream, twice a day.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Perfect, keep that up. The moisturizer is the foundation of eczema care. The steroid is just for flares.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: How long does she use the new cream?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Apply the mometasone once daily to active eczema patches only. Use it until the patches are flat and not itchy, usually five to seven days. Then stop and continue the CeraVe.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: And if it comes back?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You can restart the mometasone for another five to seven days. If she's flaring constantly, we'll talk about other options.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you for figuring this out. I felt bad that the first cream made her worse.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Not your fault at all. Allergies happen and now we know to avoid triamcinolone. Call me after you try the test area.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I will. Thanks, Doctor.
